channel.title: NYT > Business > Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: As Trump Returns to G7, Rift With Allies Is Even Deeper
item.description: In 2018, the president called for the group to embrace Russia and stormed out of the summit. Now he is seeking to shrink America’s military role abroad and embarking on a more expansive trade war.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

item.title: ‘Golden Share’ in U.S. Steel Gives Trump Extraordinary Control
item.description: Administration officials secured a deal that will give the president unusual influence over a private company, and could serve as a model for other deals.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Lauren Hirsch

item.title: Trump Steel Tariffs Expand to Hit Home Appliances Like Refrigerators and Dishwashers
item.description: The move is one of the first times this year that consumer products were specifically targeted with higher import taxes.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Alan Rappeport

item.title: Where’s the Inflation From Tariffs? Just Wait, Economists Say.
item.description: Are predictions for a jump in consumer prices too early, or just wrong?
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith

item.title: How Labor Unions Came to Define the L.A. Immigration Protests
item.description: Unions have backed immigrant rights in California and have been on the forefront of resisting the Trump administration’s deportations.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: New China Trade ‘Deal’ Takes U.S. Back to Where It Started
item.description: If a handshake agreement holds, it will merely undo some of the damage from the trade war that President Trump started.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Trump Hails Progress With China, but Details Are Sketchy
item.description: Two days of trade talks resulted in what leaders called a framework agreement meant to solidify terms of a truce that the superpowers reached in Geneva last month.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson, Alan Rappeport and Jonathan Swan

item.title: U.S. Court Agrees to Keep Trump Tariffs Intact as Appeal Gets Underway
item.description: The appeals court’s decision delivered an important but interim victory for the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm

item.title: Trump Administration Holds Trade Talks With China as Fight Over Rare Earths Escalates
item.description: Officials from the world’s largest economies will try to strike a deal Tuesday to relax painful export restrictions that they have imposed on each other.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: European Union Unveils Fresh Sanctions on Russia, Including a Nord Stream Ban
item.description: Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, announced a proposal meant to ramp up pressure on Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek

item.title: Trump Aides Urge Court to Spare Tariffs as They Dismiss Worries in Public
item.description: There are dueling narratives as the administration seeks to preserve a set of tariffs recently deemed to be illegal.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm

item.title: Democrats Hate Trump’s Policy Bill, but Love Some of Its Tax Cuts
item.description: There’s an undercurrent of Democratic support for elements of President Trump’s tax agenda, a dynamic that Republicans are trying to exploit as they make the case for enactment of their sprawling domestic legislation.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren

item.title: U.S. and China to Hold Economic Talks in London
item.description: Top American economic officials will meet with their Chinese counterparts next Monday in hopes of breaking a trade stalemate, President Trump said.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport

item.title: Marina von Neumann Whitman Dead: International Trade Expert Was 90
item.description: She was the first woman to serve on the White House Council of Economic Advisers. At General Motors, she became one of the highest-ranking women in corporate America.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: As Trump’s Tariffs Reshape Trade, Businesses Struggle With Economic Uncertainty
item.description: Policymakers and business owners are navigating a highly uncertain moment for the economy, wary of overreacting but watchful of a meaningful downturn.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith

item.title: Fired by DOGE, More Federal Workers Are Flooding the Job Market
item.description: The drastic, sudden pullback in federal dollars is collapsing opportunities for many who’ve spent years in public service.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan and Lydia DePillis

item.title: Imports Plummet in April as Trump’s Tariffs Weigh on Trade
item.description: Americans bought fewer foreign pharmaceuticals, cellphones and cars, and cut purchases of machinery and other supplies.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: How Higher Tariffs on Steel and Aluminum Will Affect Companies
item.description: Home builders, car manufacturers and can makers are among those that will see higher prices for materials. Those companies could charge customers more.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo, Neal E. Boudette and Rebecca F. Elliott

item.title: Trump’s 50% Tariffs on Steel and Aluminum Imports Go Into Effect
item.description: President Trump has doubled the rate on foreign metals to 50%, saying the levies weren’t high enough to help the U.S. industry.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Ian Austen

item.title: U.S.-China Trade War Morphs From Tariffs Into Fight Over Supply Chain
item.description: Instead of battling over tariffs, Washington and Beijing have turned to a potentially far more harmful strategy: flexing their control over global supply chains.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
